title: The Prenup Clause
premise: A fiercely independent, perpetually single event planner accidentally triggers a forgotten clause in her eccentric aunt's will: to inherit the family's historic coastal inn, she must be married within a year. In a panic, she enters a strictly business arrangement with her charming but infuriatingly laid-back rival, a local surf instructor, who needs capital to save his own business. Their contract stipulates 'no feelings, just facilitation,' but sharing a roof—and fending off skeptical townsfolk—proves that the most binding contracts are the ones written on the heart.
protagonist: Maya Vance, a type-A, spreadsheet-loving event planner whose life is a meticulously color-coded calendar.
conflict: Maya must maintain a convincing public facade of a happy marriage with her polar opposite, Leo, while battling their growing, inconvenient attraction and the terms of their ironclad prenuptial agreement, which promises a clean, emotionless split in twelve months.
setting: Present-day in the quirky, gossipy seaside town of Seabrook Cove, centered around the charming but rundown 'Harbor Light Inn.'
tone: Witty, warm, and fizzy with banter, balancing laugh-out-loud situational comedy with genuine, slow-burn romantic tension.
